item.title: IR Playbooks
item.description: These are my ideas on IR playbooks for training. Don’t judge :) We don’t evolve if we don’t make mistakes and learn from them. And we don’t make mistakes if we do nothing. Even if I am risking to become an object of ridicule, I am posting this article. I am planning to imporve once I learn more or gain some relevant experience.

item.title: FSEvents
item.description: Intro Directory events only 10.5-10.6. File events since 10.7. Each record is assigned a name which is constucted the following way: hex(last_event_id + 1).

item.title: System Supernova üí´
item.description: One of the main things to know when performing forensic analysis is knowing what’s normal and what’s not. It would take ages to google every single pinch of this information, that’s why I have decided to make a clean install of several systems and capture their state to have an idea what’s good for each of them.

item.title: Linux Artifacts
item.description: User Data /home/$USER - user data and configs Password hashes etc/passwd etc/shadow Notifications Configurations /etc[%SystemRoot%]/System32/config - contains separate configs for each application

item.title: Mac Artifacts
item.description: User Data /Users/%username%/ Password hashes sudo plutil -p /var/db/dslocal/nodes/Default/users/<usename>.plist Account Info sudo plutil -p /private/var/db/dslocal/nodes/Default/Users/<User>.plist Contains name, profile name, password hint, account image, UID

item.title: Windows Hibernation
item.description: Hibernation files store the last state of RAM before “falling asleep” üí§ . These files are of a particular value when live acquisition is impossible.

item.title: BTFM
item.description: dshell # MacOSX path to directory with pyenv (example): /Users/[user_name]/.pyenv/versions/3.8.5/envs/python3/lib/python3.8/site-packages/dshell/ decode -l # list decoders decode -d [decoder_name] # decoder info # who talked to whom decode -d ip [capture_file_name].

item.title: RAM Collection on macOS
item.description: On the forensicswiki [1] there is the list of tools to be used for RAM acquisition. I’ve tried several of them and realised, that the current problem of the forensic community is that the tools get old much faster than the information gets updated… Sadly.

item.title: Forensic Toolkit

item.description: Running netstat, see the weird python script with established connection to some remote host: Grab the executable: lsof -p 2082 and ps aux grep 2082.

item.description: Compromised Apache Web server with drupal application used for local team. There was some unusual activity noticed between 05/10 and 08/10/19.

item.title: iOS Jailbreaking
item.description: Types of jailbreaking Tethered jailbreaks don’t persist through reboots, so re-applying jailbreaks requires the device to be connected (tethered) to a computer during every reboot.

item.title: Sample Questions
item.description: List of tools List of reg entries List of known malware and ioc Terminology List of artefacts (Win and Lin) List of attacks List of scans and their footprint (try map against different OS and log the results) Re-read those diaries, might be of help Configure laboratory (Wins I have + WinXP + Linux Hacking + Linux Kali) Install WinServer VM with AD and learn the basics (Udemy course may be + Hahacking + questions) ‚ùì Which of the following encryption methods use the RC4 technology?
